results.title: From war to revolution
results.creator_credit: John Radcliffe and British Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “History 1917-1967”.
Describes the development of the main opposing forces in China in the period of the civil war and disorder following the 1911 revolution, the war with Japan and the eventual establishment of the Communist regime in 1949.

results.title: The Cold war
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “History 1917-1967”.
Describes the origin and development of the hostility between the United States and USSR after 1945, the formation of the system of anti-communist alliances around the world and the respective spheres of influence. Suitable for upper secondary level.

results.title: The Rise of Hitler
results.creator_credit: John Radcliffe, BBC-TV and British Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “History 1917-1967”
Describes the peace settlement after the 1914-18 War and its effects in Germany. Discusses the reasons for the rise of Hitler, the nature of his regime and the series of aggressive moves leading to war in 1939.

results.title: Lenin's revolution
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “History 1917-1967”.
Describes the background to the Russian revolution of 1917, Lenin’s intentions and policies and the consolidation of the Bolsheviks in power. Commentary by Brian Redhead. Suitable for upper secondary level.

results.title: Cosmos: a personal voyage
results.creator_credit: Gregory Andorfer, Rob McCain, Adrian Malone, BBC, Carl Sagan Productions, KCET (Television station : Los Angeles, Calif.) and Polytel
results.brief_description: Carl Sagan hosts this series of films which explore the mysteries of the universe and the origins of life.

constellations_other.name: A brief history of black holes on-screen
constellations_other.description: In 1916, Albert Einstein predicted black holes through his theory of general relativity. That mix of science and imagination can be seen in Marshmallow Laser Feast’s Distortions in Spacetime. These other works are fascinated by these cosmic giants and represent an evolution in computer graphics and VFX.

constellations_other.name: Future You
constellations_other.description: There are 47,000 possible variations of robot in Future You. There's probably not that many in all of screen culture, but these ones stand out.

results.title: Encyclopaedia galactica
results.creator_credit: Adrian Malone, Gregory Andorfer, BBC, Carl Sagan Productions, KCET (Television station : Los Angeles, Calif.) and Polytel
results.brief_description:
Episode number 12 of Series “Cosmos: a personal voyage”.
In this episode Carl Sagan tackles the question of the possibilities of life on other planets. In spite of the lack of compelling credible evidence that alien visitors have visited our planet, Sagan demonstrates the probability of life existing elsewhere in the universe, and some of the possible forms this life might take. He also discusses the possibility of interstellar communication and how this might be interpreted, using the example of the deciphering of Egyptian hieroglyphics by Jean Francois Champollion, posing the notion that the laws of science are a common language, a kind of Rosetta Stone.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Adrian Malone, Gregory Andorfer, BBC, Carl Sagan Productions, KCET (Television station : Los Angeles, Calif.) and Polytel

results.title: The Edge of forever
results.creator_credit: David F. Oyster, Gregory Andorfer, Adrian Malone, BBC Film Unit, Carl Sagan Productions, KCET (Television station : Los Angeles, Calif.) and Polytel International
results.brief_description:
Episode number 10 of Series “Cosmos: a personal voyage”.
What is the origin of the universe? What is its fate? Will it continue to expand forever, or someday collapse upon itself? Carl Sagan explores the time when stars and galaxies began to form, and shows how, in this century, humans discovered the expansion of the universe. He also explores the philosophical and religious questions that these musings create. Topics discussed along the way include galaxies and their many different forms, the Doppler effect, tessaracts, the Big Bang and quasars.

results.title: Journeys in space and time
results.creator_credit: Adrian Malone, Gregory Andorfer, BBC, Carl Sagan Productions, KCET (Television station : Los Angeles, Calif.) and Polytel International
results.brief_description:
Episode number 8 of Series “Cosmos: a personal voyage”.
In this episode Carl Sagan explores the relationship of space and time. He begins by showing how the shape of the constellations would change over millions of years, as the stars move and evolve, and then launches into a discussion on the speed of light and Einstein’s theory of relativity, concluding with the tantalising possibilities of time travel and parallel universes.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Adrian Malone, Gregory Andorfer, BBC, Carl Sagan Productions, KCET (Television station : Los Angeles, Calif.) and Polytel International

results.title: The Backbone of night
results.creator_credit: Adrian Malone, Gregory Andorfer, BBC, Carl Sagan Productions, KCET (Television station : Los Angeles, Calif.) and Polytel International
results.brief_description:
Episode number 7 of Series “Cosmos: a personal voyage”.
In this episode, Carl Sagan describes man’s long exploration of the cosmos as a voyage of self-discovery. His thesis that “we make our world significant by the courage of our questions and the depth of our answers” is illustrated by man’s quest to explain the cosmos through periods of intellectual growth and periods of repression. From our primitive ancestors’ ideas of the heavens, through Greek science and philosophy, to the Renaissance, the age of reason and the modern day, Sagan attempts to convey a sense of wonder and excitement about the exploration of the natural universe.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Adrian Malone, Gregory Andorfer, BBC, Carl Sagan Productions, KCET (Television station : Los Angeles, Calif.) and Polytel International
results.description:
Episode number 7 of Series “Cosmos: a personal voyage”.
In this episode, Carl Sagan describes man’s long exploration of the cosmos as a voyage of self-discovery. His thesis that “we make our world significant by the courage of our questions and the depth of our answers” is illustrated by man’s quest to explain the cosmos through periods of intellectual growth and periods of repression. From our primitive ancestors’ ideas of the heavens, through Greek science and philosophy, to the Renaissance, the age of reason and the modern day, Sagan attempts to convey a sense of wonder and excitement about the exploration of the natural universe.

results.title: Travellers' tales
results.creator_credit: Adrian Malone, Gregory Andorfer, BBC, Carl Sagan Productions, Intel and KCET (Television station : Los Angeles, Calif.)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 6 of Series “Cosmos: a personal voyage”.
In this episode Carl Sagan follows man’s passion to explore, from the Dutch sailors of the seventeenth century to the Voyager project and its rendezvous with Jupiter and its moons in 1979. He compares the change in vision that came with Christian Huygens’ study of light and astronomy in the seventeenth century and the impact of the detailed pictures sent back by the Voyager spacecraft on the scientists of today. The video includes a fairly detailed look at Jupiter and its moons and at life in seventeenth century Holland.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Adrian Malone, Gregory Andorfer, BBC, Carl Sagan Productions, Intel and KCET (Television station : Los Angeles, Calif.)
